explanation:
To determine whether get_request_line_inner violates the MISRA rule “a function parameter should not be modified” we must be able to tell (1) whether the parameter identifier 'c' itself is reassigned inside the function or by any macro/inline called here, and (2) whether only members of *c are modified (which is allowed). The items listed are therefore the minimal symbols needed to make that judgement: 

- struct MHD_Connection, struct MHD_Daemon (daemon->client_discipline), and the listed MHD_Connection member names (read_buffer, read_buffer_size, read_buffer_offset, state, rq and all rq subfields such as method, url, url_len, version, req_target_len, num_cr_sp_replaced, hdrs.rq_line.proc_pos, skipped_empty_lines, last_ws_start, last_ws_end, rq_tgt, rq_tgt_qmark, num_ws_in_uri): required to confirm that code is modifying fields of the object pointed to by the parameter (allowed by MISRA) rather than reassigning the parameter variable itself. You need the exact member declarations/types to confirm these are members and not, for example, macros or local variables named c.

- mhd_assert (macro) and MHD_ALLOW_BARE_LF_AS_CRLF_ (macro): these are invoked in the function; their definitions must be checked to ensure they do not contain statements that reassign the parameter identifier 'c' (e.g. weird macro side effects). Also confirm they do not expand into code that shadows or changes the parameter.

- _ (gettext macro) and the error token macros (BARE_CR_IN_HEADER, BARE_LF_IN_HEADER, REQUEST_MALFORMED, RQ_LINE_TOO_MANY_WSP): included because they appear in calls; if any are implemented as macros that expand to code touching the local variable 'c' (unlikely but possible in some projects) they must be inspected.

- Declarations/definitions of the called functions (connection_close_error, transmit_error_response_static/transmit_error_response_len, parse_http_version, parse_http_std_method): needed to check whether any of these are actually implemented as macros/inline functions that might reassign the local parameter variable name 'c' (or expand in-place to code that does). If they are regular functions taking 'c' as an argument they may modify *c (allowed) but will not reassign the local parameter variable; verifying their signatures/definitions rules this out.

- Constants used as control values (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING, MHD_HTTP_MTHD_NO_METHOD, MHD_HTTP_MTHD_GET, MHD_HTTP_MTHD_DELETE, HTTP_VER_LEN, MHD_MAX_EMPTY_LINES_SKIP): required to understand control-flow and assertions; if any of these are macros that expand to code (rare) they must be checked to ensure they do not reassign the parameter.

In short: obtain the type definitions of MHD_Connection and related nested types, the macro definitions used in the function, and the declarations/definitions of the callees and constants. With those symbols you can prove whether only members of *c are changed (allowed) and whether the parameter identifier 'c' is ever reassigned (violation).
